title: 111_hr2134
content: The Act may be cited as the "Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission Act of 2009". Congress finds that in 2008, there were millions of users of marijuana, cocaine, methamphetamine, and heroin in the United States. The majority of cocaine and heroin in the US originates from Andean countries and Colombia and Mexico, respectively, leading to violence and corruption in those regions. Additionally, drug trafficking in Central America, Mexico, and other countries contributes to instability. Drug trafficking originating in Colombia and Mexico leads to violence, instability, and corruption in those countries. In Central America, Mexico, Venezuela, Ecuador, Haiti, and other Caribbean countries, drug trafficking strengthens organized criminals, threatening law enforcement, political institutions, and citizen security. Drug-related violence is increasing in Mexico and along the US-Mexico border, with 5,661 deaths in 2008 alone. Drug-related violence is rising in Mexico and along the US-Mexico border, with 5,661 deaths in Mexico in 2008 alone. Organized criminal networks in Mexico traffic women and girls into the US for sexual exploitation. Extremist groups like FARC and Hezbollah use drug trafficking to fund terrorist activities in the Western Hemisphere. United States counternarcotics assistance has been provided to Latin America from 1980-2008. Extremist groups in the Western Hemisphere, such as FARC and Hezbollah, finance terrorist activities through drug trafficking. United States provided $11.3 billion in counternarcotics assistance to Latin America and the Caribbean from 1980-2008. Establishment of an independent commission called the "Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission" to review and evaluate US policy on illicit drug supply reduction and interdiction, focusing on international drug policies in the Western Hemisphere. The Commission will identify policy options to enhance existing counternarcotics efforts. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will review US policies on illicit drug supply reduction, interdiction, and demand reduction. It will assess international drug control policies, interdiction efforts, crop eradication programs, and economic development alternatives. The impact of various initiatives on curbing drug production and trafficking will be evaluated, along with strategies for better deployment and employment. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will assess the impact of initiatives like the Andean Counterdrug Initiative and the Merida Initiative on curbing drug production and trafficking. It will also evaluate efforts to target major drug cartels using technology and curb the trafficking of chemical precursors for illicit drugs. Additionally, the commission will review the United States drug certification process, the population's demand for illicit drugs, and drug prevention efforts. The certification process evaluates US international illicit drug control policies, assesses population demand for illicit drugs, reviews drug prevention and treatment programs, and makes recommendations to improve policies aimed at reducing drug supply and demand. The curr_chunk discusses recommendations for improving US policies on reducing the supply and demand for illicit drugs, assessing support for drug control in other countries, and evaluating the indicators of success in US drug control policy. The Commission will consult with various leaders and organizations in the Western Hemisphere to assess the effectiveness of illicit drug control policies. They will also work with the Inter-American Drug Abuse Control Commission to identify potential improvements. A report must be submitted within 12 months of the Commission's first meeting. The Commission will submit a report to relevant committees within 12 months of its first meeting to assess and improve illicit drug control policies in the Western Hemisphere. The Commission will submit a report to relevant committees containing recommendations, findings, and conclusions, as well as input from leaders and organizations consulted. The report will be made available to the public. SEC. 6. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of ten members appointed by various leaders, excluding current government officials. Each member serves for the Commission's duration, with vacancies filled promptly. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission shall appoint members within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Within 60 days, they will hold an initial meeting to select a Chairperson and develop a review schedule. Six members constitute a quorum, and members receive travel expenses as per regulations. The Commission appoints members within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Within 60 days, they hold an initial meeting to select a Chairperson. Six members constitute a quorum. Members receive travel expenses as per regulations. SEC. 7. POWERS. The Commission has the power to hold meetings, conduct hearings, and access necessary resources from various government agencies to carry out its duties. The Commission has the authority to access resources from government agencies, use the United States mails, and enter into contracts as needed to fulfill its duties. The Commission has the authority to use the United States mails and enter into contracts with various entities to fulfill its duties. SEC. 8. STAFF. The Commission shall have an Executive Director who can appoint staff as needed, paid at a rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission may appoint additional personnel without following certain regulations, but their pay cannot exceed a specified limit. The Commission's Executive Director can appoint staff as needed, paid at a rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission may also procure temporary services and detail government employees to assist in its duties. The Commission's Executive Director can appoint staff as needed at a rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. Federal agencies may detail personnel to assist the Commission under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, without interrupting their civil service status or privileges. Authorization of appropriations for $2,000,000 without fiscal year limitation. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting its report to Congress.
